meta_data.title: JERS: A Unified Framework for Joint Brain Extraction, Registration, and Segmentation
meta_data.abstract: This paper introduces JERS, an end-to-end framework for joint brain extraction, registration, and segmentation. It addresses challenges in performing these tasks without individual task labels by using a single labeled template. JERS integrates modules for each task, enabling joint learning and optimization. Extensive experiments on public brain MRI datasets demonstrate its superior performance compared to state-of-the-art techniques.

relate work.related papers: Smith et al. introduced a deformable model for brain extraction. Other techniques utilize edge detection and filtering. The registration domain has seen both conventional techniques and deep learning methods like RegNet. In segmentation, CNN-based approaches dominate, although they often require a large dataset. Joint registration and segmentation efforts have shown promising improvements.
relate work.comparisons with related methods: Compared to traditional methods, JERS offers an integrated approach that concurrently handles extraction, registration, and segmentation, yielding better performance metrics and facilitating joint optimization.

high_level_summary.summary of this paper: The paper introduces JERS, a framework that jointly learns and optimizes brain extraction, registration, and segmentation tasks using a single labeled template. It eliminates the need for individual task annotations, streamlining neuroimaging processes.
high_level_summary.research purpose: To develop an efficient, integrated approach for brain extraction, registration, and segmentation using a unified framework.
high_level_summary.research challenge: Traditional methods require laborious annotations and often treat tasks separately, missing the inter-task dependencies that could enhance performance.
high_level_summary.method summary: JERS employs a deep neural network architecture with extraction, registration, and segmentation modules, trained jointly to improve overall task performance.
high_level_summary.conclusion: JERS successfully streamlines multiple neuroimaging processes into a single framework, achieving superior accuracy and efficiency compared to existing methods.

Method.description: The JERS framework integrates extraction, registration, and segmentation into an end-to-end neural network structure. Each task is represented by a module that interacts with others for enhanced learning.
Method.model: A unified neural network architecture that incorporates task-specific modules for extraction, registration, and segmentation.

Experiments.hyperparameters: Extraction and registration stages are set to 5. The segmentation loss parameter is 0.1 and extraction mask smooth parameter is 1.
Experiments.results: JERS outperforms baseline methods in extraction, registration, and segmentation tasks across all tested datasets.
Experiments.performance: Demonstrates superior accuracy, robustness, and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods.

conclusion.summary: JERS integrates extraction, registration, and segmentation into a single framework for neuroimaging, enhancing task performance and efficiency without the need for extensive individual task annotations.
